title: Lag issues in League even though I'm getting 400 mbps internet
body:
I have had an issue the past few months where I get on to play league and my ms will be in the 300+ range even though I have 300mbps internet speed and a really fast new cpu. If I create my own game and keep leaving and making a new one, eventually ill join and my ms will be constant at 39ms. which is what I normally get. But as soon as I join a new game it will jump right back to 300+. I don't understand this because when it is at 39ms it will stay that way throughout the whole match but then the next game jumps up. I've already had 3 tech guys from time warner come out and check everything. Im on my third modem. None of them were able to figure out what was wrong.

Notes: Yes i am hardwired into the modem with cat6 cable. I normally have around 432 mbps download speed.

replies.body:
Downlink speeds (432Mbps) rarely impact the latency you'll see between you and a server. This is because the two are almost entirely unrelated. Downlink speed helps determine at which (data) rate you can receive data from a server, while latency determines the measurable time it takes for a packet to hit a server and then come back to your PC. Latency (ping) issues are by far the most common issue we see from players, and they're most often caused by an issue along network routing or by a local network configuration that doesn't play well with League. In order to troubleshoot this further, we'll need to ensure your local network settings are in good standing by having you work through our [**connection guide.**](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752664-Troubleshooting-Connection-Issues)

Please let me know if you continue to see high latency in-game after taking those steps.
I tried all of this. Still does it...

In this case, we can run some traceroute logs to take a closer look at your network routing to our servers. I'd like you to use a network app called [**WinMTR**](http://winmtr.net/) to complete this. After loading up the app, simply plug **104.160.131.1** into the host field before you start the trace. After the trace has run for 5 minutes or longer, export the results as text and paste them in a reply to me.

If you run into any issues with those tasks, hit me up.

As mentioned by *Kristari*, your latency just inside your home network experiences some pretty nasty spikes of 429ms, according to this traceroute. If your router/modem were provided by your ISP, you may want to reach out to them regarding any available firmware updates or factory resetting and reconfiguring your home network equipment. The rest of your route shows consistently high latency which could be caused by a bad modem/router as well. Reaching out to a tier 2 agent or a supervisor over at your ISP's technical support and providing this traceroute may be the best course of action from here.

Let me know if you have any questions.

Since we've narrowed down the issue to problems along your network routing and inside your home network, continuing to work with your ISP is the best course of action right now. Since your ISP your only contact point for launching an investigation into your routing issues, you'll need to finish troubleshooting this with your ISP's support.

If you have any other concerns, let me know.

I've changed the Ethernet cable 2 times. It's a cat 6 cable ,both were.

As for the router, I've replaced it 3 times! I have had 3 different ones....
I just hate Time warner because no other internet provider has ever given me a problem

I'd check other sites to see if you get the same results (just as a sanity check), and if you are, I personally would do the following:

I'd replace your ethernet cable, check again, and if you get the same result I'd have them replace your router.

You have a 429 ping (worst captured) between your rig and the router...
